title: 109_hr4356
content: The Act titled "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" enhances penalties for fraud related to major disaster or emergency benefits. The Act "Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005" amends Chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code by adding a section on fraud in connection with major disaster or emergency benefits. It outlines penalties for falsifying information or making fraudulent statements related to benefits authorized in connection with a major disaster or emergency declaration. The Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005 imposes penalties for fraud related to benefits authorized in connection with a major disaster or emergency declaration. Violators can face fines, imprisonment for up to 30 years, or both for actions such as transportation, transmission, or disbursement of fraudulent benefits affecting interstate or foreign commerce. The Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005 imposes penalties for fraud related to benefits authorized in connection with a major disaster or emergency declaration. The term 'benefit' is defined as any record, voucher, payment, money, or thing of value provided by the government or other entity. SEC. 3 and SEC. 4 of the Emergency and Disaster Assistance Fraud Penalty Enhancement Act of 2005 increase criminal penalties for engaging in wire, radio, television, and mail fraud during and in relation to a presidentially declared major disaster or emergency. Section 1341 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include fraud related to benefits in connection with a presidentially declared disaster or emergency. The United States Sentencing Commission is required to increase penalties for fraud or theft offenses related to major disaster or emergency declarations. They must also submit an explanation of their actions and any policy recommendations to Congress. The Sentencing Commission must ensure that sentencing guidelines reflect the seriousness of specified offenses and the need for law enforcement action. They should maintain consistency with other directives, consider mitigating circumstances, make necessary guideline changes, and align with sentencing purposes outlined in the law. The Sentencing Commission must promptly promulgate guidelines or amendments within 30 days of the enactment of this Act, in accordance with specified procedures. The House of Representatives passed the Act on June 20, 2006. Karen L. Haas attested to it as the Clerk.
